byline.contributor: Jess Bidgood contributed reporting from Boston; Julie Turkewitz from Denver; and Jennifer Crossley Howard from Decatur, Ala.

abstract: Hillary Clinton's presidential candidacy is revealing generational schism among female voters, with older women viewing election of female president as important and younger women expressing other concerns; older women recall struggles to break glass ceiling and want to see efforts validated by Clinton's election, while younger women say candidate's gender is less important than their views.

headline.print_headline: Clinton’s Bid Shows Divide for Women
headline.main: Hillary Clinton’s Candidacy Reveals Generational Schism Among Women

snippet: Many younger women identify strongly with their generation’s collective concerns, in contrast with older women who have focused on a woman reaching the presidency.
lead_paragraph: Many younger women identify strongly with their generation’s collective concerns, in contrast with older women who have focused on a woman reaching the presidency.
